participants.participant: Corrado Passera, Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to Paolo's conference call. The CEO, Mr. Corrado Passera report on Paolo's 2008 Half Yearly Results. In the presentation, we will be following session for analysts only.
Now, I hand over to Mr. Corrado. Please.

Good afternoon and good morning to some of you. Thank you for joining us today. A few words before we go through the pages of the presentation. I'm very satisfied with the performance of our Group in the first half of 2008. These first six months of the year have been marked outside by a number of difficulties on the market and in a number of countries, by declining economic confidence.

On the other side we believe that we have delivered in four key areas and the main ones are our operating performance, both in terms of revenues and cost control. We have reconfirmed the strength of our balance sheet. You will see that the ratio between net doubtful loans and loans keeps remaining very low, below 1%. At the same time the liquidity position is strong; it's even stronger than last time we presented our figures at the end of March.

Another reason why I'm very satisfied with what we have done is the speed of the integration. We wanted to anticipate the complete integration of our IT system and we have done it by July; that's very important because the integration, the availability of the same IT system throughout the Group makes possible a number of activities. And this integration of the IT system is one of the engines of growth that we are in the process of creating and that will deliver growth in the future.

A last point before we go through the presentation, the importance of capital and equity. You will see that we remain committed, both to our 6% target for quarter one and to the dividend payout we had announced in our business plan for 2007, 2008, and 2009. Our confidence comes from the fact that the operating performance is going reasonably in the direction we wanted. At the same time, as we announced on a number of occasions, we have identified more than €8 billion worth of non-core assets, the sale of which will have a very substantial effect on our ratios.

Let's now go through the presentation. In the first pages you'll find all the notes that are needed to understand the way we consolidate and the way we compare figures quarter-after-quarter. The first real page is page number two, and here we have the main, the summary of the main achievements. We talk about adjusted figures because in both the first semester of this year and the first semester last year, we enjoyed a number of non-ordinary items; so a number of extraordinary results that, in our opinion, should be kept aside in order to understand, evaluate the operating performance of our company.

At the same time, trading profits have been so different in the first six months of last year and this year that we intend to extract them and keep them aside too, in order to understand that the real underlying performance of our bank.

Bottom line of the period was 3.1 billion, adjusted in the way I said before, that is, excluding profits on trading and the main non-recurrent items, is up 22%. In the comparison, you see that operating revenues are up 2% and operating margin up 8%. Cost control is very strict, and the decline by almost 3% is an achievement, much stronger than what we provided for in the business plan. Asset quality is confirmed, with cost of credit in line with our business plan target and, as I said before, the net doubtful loans ratio is stable at 0.9%.

Liquidity profile, very strong; customer deposits keep exceeding loans to customers, and at the end of June we had even a positive net inter-bank position. We believe that liquidity will remain a very important issue, and might even become a more important issue between the end of this year and the beginning of next year, because of the number of bond issues on the market that will expire during those periods. Last point is the point I mentioned before about our integration process; that is certainly running ahead of schedule, and the completion of the IT system, six months in advance is a good evidence of it. 100,000 new customers, goes with the first items I mentioned before, and that is one of the reasons why our revenues keep growing.

Page number three and page number four are pages that you can use to understand which items we extracted, both non-recurring items and the profits on trading; and you can reconcile the figures I mentioned before with the figures of our P&L. Page number three is for the whole semester while page number two – sorry, page number four is the comparison between the second quarter 2008 and the second quarter 2007.

Page number five is again the liquidity position; loans to customers less than the customer deposits and, the inter-bank position at 8 billion positive. Page number six, P&L of the whole group at the end of June. The black figures are the accounting ones, while in the yellow clouds you find the adjusted figures.

We will go through all these lines in the following pages, but let me just focus your attention on the first line of the P&L. We keep enjoying a growth in net interest income that is very sound, is certainly higher than what we forecasted in our business plan, and since interest income counts for more than 50% of our total revenues, that's an important – that has an important effect.

Operating costs look growing but, as I mentioned before, the real performance is close to 3% less than last year, and that's because, last year, we had a special effect – a special fiscal effect because of a change in the provisions. So the real figure is -2.8. What else? No – let's go to page number seven. Page number seven is the P&L of the second quarter this year, versus the same period last year. You see that interest rates – interest income keeps growing, more or less at the same speed. And we will now analyze the interest income.

And page number eight, we have only the breakdown of our revenues. In order to make clear that more than 80% of our revenues come from retail activities, mainly in our Italian – from our Italian network but to a growing extent, also through our International Subsidiary Banks Division.

Page number nine is what I was mentioning before, net interest income. That accounts for almost 60% – I said, more than 50% but, actually, it's 60% of our operating income. The main drivers of the 11% increase, on a year on year basis, were the 9% increase in average customer loans; so, volumes and, improvement in mark-down.

Contribution to the growth comes from practically all business units, retail loans up 5.9%. SMEs, where we tend to be a little more prudent, is 5.2%. Corporate has increased its' volume at two-digit speed, 17.5% but they keep a very selective approach in order to keep the quality of our credit loans. 7.7% is the growth of public finance while the International Subsidiary Banks division has grown by almost 27%.

If we look at the right-hand side of the page we see the positive trend in the quarterly figures and this quarter, like last quarter, was the best quarter ever. On a quarterly basis we have grown 2.8% from -between the first and the second quarter of this year. As I will say also afterwards, we have been very good at keeping a very selective lending policy and we have been good at withstanding the mark-down figures. I must tell you and my colleagues know that very well; we all agree that we can do better on the mark-up part of this trend. And, we have identified a significant portion of our customers that will be entertained in some discussions because there is room for re-pricing.

Page number 10, with the analysis of the net interest income; most of it, 74% is related to the growth in customer volumes and 26% of the increase was due to improvements in operating spread – no, sorry, yes, yes, yes, yes. So almost all of it comes from operation and a good part of that comes from volumes; but as you see, spreads are also contributing to the result.

Page number 11, net fee and commission income; obviously we are not happy about the results. We have to look at the different elements more in depth because if we look at commercial banking activities, commissions are more or less stable and this stability is a good – means a good performance, given the kind of effect that the merger created in terms of alignment to the lowest price products.

While the rest, the commissions from management dealing in consultancy services; that means portfolio management, insurance products and placement of securities. That is the part of the commission portfolio that is going down, almost 10%. There is certainly a market reason and there is certainly a growing risk aversion by practically all segments of the customer base.

People tend to keep their money in more – in less risky kind of investment and, in fact, when we will look at the development of the total financial assets of our customers, we will see that the total amounts, the total volumes that they keep with us is even growing. But they are shifting their investment from assets under management to assets under administration. We are working on it. We are preparing a number of actions to balance this trend.

We are investing a lot of money in training a number of people; so, a very large number of people that will be more capable to entertain our customers on these kinds of products and services. But I don't expect a real change in these trends until something happens on the market. And people keep very uncertain about financial markets.

The day markets change or the day the confidence in the market changes, the amount of growth, the change in speed that we might then enjoy can be very significant because, as you might remember, we are talking about almost one trillion of financial assets of people, of customers, we deal with.

At page number 12 you have the figures that prove the point I made before. If you look on the left-hand side you'll see that assets under management decreased by more than €14 billion. At the same time the amount of assets under administration grew by more than 13 billion.

Customer deposits grew in a very significant way and the total effect of these three trends makes the total of the financial assets we manage, in a way or another, for our customers grew by almost €3 billion. On the right-hand side, you have the trend in new customer numbers that in the first quarter of 2008 grew by almost or around 100,000 new customers.

Profit on trading, profit on trading we are going exactly the way we wanted to; given the market conditions we have been able – despite the market conditions, we have been able to deliver a solid contribution to our overall revenues. You see – you remember that in the last quarter of last year we had, for the first and only time, a negative figure.

We committed to get back to a positive figure in first quarter 2008 and that was done. And, in the second quarter 2008, we are getting back to a reasonable figure. Let's not forget that last year we decided to squeeze the financial activities held for trading and the reduction was a massive one, almost €30 billion.

At page 14, if we look at the breakdown of the trading profits you know that we subdivide them in four different components. The customer activities, you know that quarter after quarter these figures are getting back to a sound level.

Capital markets and financial assets for sale; this line is very dependent on specific deals we make with the assets managed by our merchant banking division. But you know that we are more or less in – on the right track.

Proprietary trading and treasury, that's where we reduced the amount of assets held by the group; we had one quarter with a negative figure but I don't expect it to happen any more. And, we are back to a reasonable figure.

The structured credit products; it's a portfolio managed separately and that's where we had, at the end of last year, an almost €400 million worth of devaluations. The kind of effect we are suffering from, the trends on the market is reducing quarter after quarter and we are more or less in the ground we expected.

Structured credit products, you will find in the presentation all the details, all the components of each single kind of credit products we hold in the group. And those will be in the annexes of the presentation. We just added two pages in the main presentation to remind that 100% of our structured credit product is in the investment grade levels, most of it super senior and AAA; almost 75% of the structured credit products are in vintages 2005 or earlier than that. And, only 9% of the whole portfolio comes from US residential facilities.

Page 16, the figure, the figure we have in US subprime, the same way we had in the previous quarter, the position is negative, 14 million negative; that means that our short positions are higher than our long positions, 47 and 33 respectively.

Page 17, page 17 confirms, let me use the word, excellent cost control; at the same time we keep investing for growth and we have not reduced any development -- any investment or cost for developing the group. Adjusted operating costs are down, almost 3% year on year, and the cost income ratio is in the round of 50%.

Adjusted personnel expenses decreased by 3.7%, actually, this was more than that because we are growing our costs in a number of countries outside of Italy. So in Italy we are doing even better than the 3.7%. The other administrative expenses are flat and the adjustments are in the round of minus 7.5%. Overall the operating costs in Italy have decreased 4.4%, while the operating cost in the international subsidiary banks division was up 12%, as provided in our budget. That's more or less it. I will go more in depth if any question will arise.

Page number 18 compares the reduction in costs we are enjoying in this first part of the business plan, period, and the target we had in the business plan. You might remember that the business plan target was minus 0.4 and we always, both in 2007 and in the first part of 2008, exceeded this level. We had to anyhow because revenues are lower than what we expected but this means that our capability, the capability and the will of the Group to react to adverse market conditions on revenues with further actions on cost.

These figures do not include any, yet, the further reduction of 2,500 people by 2009 that we have agreed upon with the trade unions. And, that will also lead to the hiring of some 100 new people but the further reduction we have already agreed with the trade unions is not yet embedded in any of our figures.

Overall, cost -- overall operating cost synergies, the three years add -- page number 19, add clear targets to be achieved. We are on track because the cumulative synergies we have realized so far are in the round of 550 million, the rest that is still to be done in 2008 will be done; and then, we have a big step upward in 2009. That will be mostly connected with IT costs.

Page number 20, provision for risk and charges; lower than last year, as planned. Net adjustment to loans reflect the high quality of our loan portfolio; that means 712 million and that implies an annual cost of credit in line with the business plan target.

Page 21, we confirm, as I was saying before, the asset quality, that the asset quality is in line with our estimates and with our targets and with the European best practice. Because, if we look at the net doubtful loans and the other categories, net substandards and net due in June 2008. We see that the net doubtful loans on net loans is stable at 0.9%. Doubtful loans are -- have a coverage of 71% and on top of that, the group has accumulated a €2.4 billion of generic reserves on older performing loans.

The flow -- yeah, that's an important point. The flow of new non-performing loans in Italy is stable, is more or less the same amount we had in the first quarter -- in the first half of 2007, and is concentrated in the Banca dei Territori Division, the retail private and SMEs division of the group. And it's a more or less equally distributed among the different customer segments. The increase in past due that here is the only component of non-performing loans, we will have to understand better; it's concentrated in the leasing and industrial credit sector, but they are certainly under control.

Capital ratios, some comments are needed here. Core Tier 1 at 5.7%, Tier 1 at 6.6%, total capital ratio's 9.5%, total risk weighted asset in the round of 390 million -- billion, sorry. Basel 2 standard, we are applying Basel 2 standardized; if we apply Basel 2 foundation the increase might be in the round of 30, 40 basis points and, if we get to Basel 2 IRB that would mean probably 30 or 40 more basis points.

We have included in the calculation of the ratios the dividends we expected and we expect to distribute on 2008 results in the spring of 2009. That means that we have already included dividends in the round of 1.800 -- €1.8 billion. In the figures we have not yet included, because they happened after the end of the semester, the disposal of Carifano that will have the six basis points. We are now close to closing a deal to sell our real estate company, the company we wanted to list it, and that would bring other several basis points.

But, as I said before, in the pipeline we have a number of disposals of non-core assets. The total amount we announced in the previous conference meetings was in the round of 8 billion, and I confirm it, but are 8 billion with a very strong component of Core Tier 1 in the round of €4 billion.

What I can tell you, as a summary on this page, is that we are committed to keep the 6% Core Tier 1. It's a policy we announced a number of months ago. We have decreased -- we have reduced, and at the end eliminated, the excess capital we had in the Group, as announced when we presented the business plan, but the 6% Core Tier 1 is confirmed. But also the dividends we had planned for the 2008 and 2009 years are confirmed.
Let's go to page number 23, it's the breakdown of the Group results for the different divisions, very rapidly through each of them.

Page 24 is the Banca dei Territori. Again, in the yellow clouds you have the real comparable figures between first semester last year and first semester this year; 2% growth in revenues, minus 2% in terms of cost, and overall result growing 10 point -- almost 11%. These are good figures because you have to remember that in this first part of 2008, we have gone through the hardest part of the integration process on the IT side. And, at the same time, we have not yet realized what we had planned for the year 2008. That was to increase significantly the number of people on the front part of the branches.

So some of the engines that are due to be realized in this division have not yet been realized, and they will be realized in the next few months. At the same time, for sure, the impact of the IT integration has had some cost in terms of results.
Page number 25 is only to remember the achievement in terms of IT integration. Six months in advance versus the plan, the merger plan.

Page 26, Eurizon Capital, for sure, this company is suffering from the crisis of the asset management products on the market. At the same time, this company has been able to react in an effective way in terms of cost. So if we see some decrease in terms of revenue, we also see a very significant effort in terms of cost reduction. So, at the end, we have an effect, but we are talking about a bit less than -- a bit more than 10 million in terms of bottom line.

Page 27, Corporate and Investment Banking, very strong performance if we keep for a moment aside the prop trading component of the Corporate and Investment Banking division. They have been charged with the management of our prop trading portfolio. But if we look at the real figure of their industrial operations, you see revenue growing by almost 9%, operating margin growing by almost 20%, and income before tax, that is the bottom line of the division, growing more than 30%.

If we look at the following page, page 28, we see the different components of the Corporate and Investment Banking division revenues -- results. And you see that all the department of the division are growing and providing stronger results to the division. Corporate relations means large and mid-corporate customers, financial institutions, international network is self-explanatory.

Capital market remain a low figure, but growing and at the level we want to have it. Investment banking is more or less in line with last year. That was a good year for investment banking. Merchant banking is very much dependent on when you make one deal, and so the volatility of the quarterly results of this department is obvious.

Then, if you put together all these figures and you exclude for a second the proprietary trading, you have a growth of almost 9%. That is in excess of what their budget target provided for. Prop trading is down, but very difficult to avoid it.
29, page 29, Public Finance, in line with the target, and growing in a very difficult but very important segment of the market.

Page number 30, International Subsidiary Banks, growing steadily, steadily without forcing too much growth and without taking risk we are not available to take. Having said that, operating income, if we exclude the trading profit, is almost 20% up, operating margin, almost 30% up, and bottom line, 36% up. Cost to income in the round of 45%, that is perfectly in line with the target.

Banca Fideuram is suffering like all its competitors from the trends in the market we mentioned before. People are -- have become and keep remaining very risk averse, and the different mix in asset under management and asset under administration has reduced a little bit their revenues, 5%. This company too is reacting reasonably well in terms of cost control. And despite they are a bit lower than what the budget provided, we expect that they could recover in the second part of the year.

Conclusion, in our opinion, the overall picture of our Group is, I would say, solid performance despite the difficult economic environment. We believe we have taken all the necessary actions to ensure the risk and the liquidity profiles we want to keep. We have increased our attention on cost control, and in that area we're certainly running ahead of our business plan target. The capital adequacy position remains, in our opinion, very secure and the capital management options I mentioned before will strengthen the figures in the next month.

What can I say about the rest of the year? The outlook remains challenging but we are very confident that we can ride out of the economic problems and difficulties. And that's why we have confirmed our dividend policy, and that's why we are accelerating in the drive in the construction of the drivers of growth that the business plan provided for, and that have to be ready by the end of this month to be at full speed next year.
Let's move to the question and answers part of the conference call.
Thank you. First question comes from Mr. Marcello Zanardo from KBW. Mr. Zanardo, please proceed with your question.

Yes. Good afternoon, Mr. Passera. It's Marcello Zanardo from Keefe Bruyette & Woods. And good numbers, so well done, congratulations. The first question is on capital. I just would like to have an idea, you mentioned you have 8 billion of potential asset for sale with a significant 4 billion. These things will be in ongoing negotiations, obviously, but just to have your feeling, how easy are you finding to deal with counterparties in a struggling market? I mean, is there a lot of interest for this kind of assets?

The price is always – is clearly getting more difficult to get, but just to have a feeling of the assets you have at the disposal, what you are finding. Obviously, I don't expect you to go into details, but just to give some more flavor on this.

And the second question's on asset quality. Your Group is the merger of what Sanpaolo used to be, a very good bank with a solid credit risk, and if I remember correctly, the former Intesa sold more than 10 billion non-performing loans, a few years ago; you deleveraged the bank.

And it's also good to see that you have 2.5 billion of reserves on performing loans, so that's a good cushion. But also, if I look at the figures which you showed before, with the net non-performing loans annualizing, so June to December times two, because I don't have the June and June numbers, up 13% and the net watch list up 20%.

So given what I said, and given the solidity of your Group, can you give here a bit more flavor on what you think provisions are going to be, loan provisions are going to be in 2008, and most importantly in 2009? Because, like you said before, lower costs are compensating for lower revenues, especially on the fee income. We might see perhaps a bit higher provision, considering that the environment has changed. So that will be very useful if you could add something here.

And the third and final question is on M&A. You pointed out at the beginning of the call that liquidity will become very important. I think so. I agree. So I would like to know if, given the commitment of your dividend per shares and your Core Tier 1 target, is correct to assume that any potential deal which will come after potentially appealing conditions, i.e., price and governance, is in this market an add-on deal, i.e., a fairly small deal, or if something fairly big could become, and I have in mind something abroad. Maybe later on you would be ready to take that opportunity, maybe sacrifice the dividend commitment because you are saying, this is such a good opportunity that it is good for the strategic group in the near future to take it, and perhaps sacrifice dividend and capital for a short period of time, or you would stick to your guidance and say I'm not going to do this, but I'm ready to do any add-on deal which is complementary? Thank you.

Okay. First question is about capital management actions; in other words, sale or participation of our shareholdings we have in the Group. Your question is how easy is today negotiating disposal of assets. It's a good question, and it's very different in the different segments. There are assets that today are certainly not accepted by the markets, or even by investors, and that's why we have, for example, postponed the listing of Fideuram.

At the same time, we have a unique assets that might be very important for industrial investors. And for that kind of assets, the crisis around is really not very significant, and the interest they are showing in the discussion we are having is very high. So today, you have to be wise enough not to push the sale of assets that the market do not – is not eager to buy, and concentrate your efforts on those unique situations that, despite the market, remain very interesting for industrial more than financial investors.

On asset quality, we really don't see any reason for changing the guidance we gave for 2008, that is 40 basis points or something in the round of 40 basis points. We will have to see, during the remaining part of the year, how the market, if the market changes, what the addition of the net doubtful loans to the portfolio of non-performing loans in the first semester of the year is very much in line with what we had last year. So it's not in evidence for changing our forecast, at least for the time being.

M&A. I tend to agree with what you said, in the sense that we consider the 6% Core Tier 1 floor level as a constraint and we don't want to lose in any occasion and for no reason. The kind of disposal we might enjoy in the next, let's say, 12 months might be the way to finance a small, very focused acquisitions. But let me tell you that today we don't have anything on the table, and I don't expect anything for a number of months.
Thank you.
Next question comes from Mr. Eugenio Cicconetti from Dresdner Kleinwort. Mr. Cicconetti, please proceed with your question.
Good evening, Mr. Passera. Couple of questions. The first is on the repricing activity still ongoing.
I cannot hear you very well. I know we are talking about the first question, but I cannot hear you.
Can you hear me now, Mr. Passera? Is better?
Much better.

Okay. Sorry about that. I was saying, the first question is on repricing activity. You tell us – you told us that is still ongoing, so I was wondering if you could, please, add some more color on spreads, to what kind of trend do you expect in the near future, in terms of mark-up and markdown, respectively?

Second question is on your book composition; if you could please give us the percentage of SMEs that is in your loan book? And the third question is the detail, if it's possible to have it, the exposure toward Mr. Zoleski. Thank you.

The repricing strategy. It's an ongoing effort, I agree with you. We have provided our divisions, departments, branches, and account managers with figures and reports that enable them to identify those customers that have share of wallet opportunities, but especially EVA positive or negative, and a number of other elements for deciding. We already see that the effect of the provision of these reports in a number of commercial areas of the Group, and we are strongly encouraging both the Corporate Division and the Banca dei Territori division to extend their use of those reports to the overall portfolio. It's mainly on – the real areas for improvement is in the area of mark-ups, because markdowns are being managed very, very, very effectively.

For sure, what is happening is that the real cost of fund that has changed rapidly and suddenly in the last month is not yet moved to the customer in the proper way. So it will certainly engage our account management people for the next six to 12 months, and it will be a never-ending exercise. In terms of the weight of SMEs on our total loan portfolio, they represent 11% of the overall portfolio of the Group. And as far as Zoleski's is concerned, it's a customer, it's – we don't provide figures for any of our customers.
I understand. Thank you.
Thank you.
Next question comes from Mr. Andrea Bua from Morgan Stanley. Mr. Bua, please proceed with your question.

Yes, good afternoon. My first question is on commission income. Mr. Passera, you clearly said that you are not happy with the performance on this area. I was wondering if, within the tactical and strategical options which you're considering or still considering, an external solution, as it was for GAM a few months ago?

Second, on costs, with 550 million of synergies achieved in the first half, my question is if you're expecting synergies to be higher than planned this year, so above the 730 millions planned, with an improvement in end timing. And on capital, if you can please give us the Core Tier ratio under Basel I to have a comparison with the previous quarters. Thank you.

First question, commission, I mentioned some tactical and commercial initiatives we are taking, and we will certainly devote a lot of attention to the improvement of the performance of the factories, but very much also to the performance of the sales network. Because these are products that are becoming more and more difficult, even if they are simple investment funds, so the kind of efforts and the kind of focalization you have to assure on a part of the sales network is crucial in increasing and improving the results of this activity.

As far as strategic options, we have already abandoned the idea of purchasing, of buying other asset management companies. We have not – we cannot exclude, as of today, the combination of with other players in this area. Nothing on the table that theoretically speaking, that might be a way to improve the performance of the whole company or part of our company. We exclude the selling of this activity.

So the only strategic external options we consider is in the area of combining some or all our activities with other players, but, again, nothing on the table. Cost synergies will be higher than the business plan provide for, both at the end of this year, and at the end of next year. Under Basel I, the core tier 1 would be more or less the same. You can make an estimate in round of 10 basis points less than what we have according to Basel II standardized.
Thank you very much.
Next question comes form Mr. Antonio Guglielmi form Merrill Lynch. Mr. Guglielmi please proceed with your question.

Good afternoon, Mr. Passera. You mentioned in your introduction 8.3 billion net positive interbank position. If I am not wrong, this is the first quarter where I can see such a positive position. Can you elaborate a bit more, and can we expect this to remain in place in the coming quarter?

Secondly, 35% quarterly growth in bancassurance, although from an admittedly low level in Q1, is still quite remarkable. Again, if you can add a few words on this? 8 billion capital management action; any chance you can give us an idea of the earnings impact of this? Four, restructuring charges, is it over, or there is something left, especially on the Diferensa side? And finally, if possible, a guidance on the tax rate? Thank you.

I'm not sure I got all your questions, but we will go through them and then you will correct me if I have not understood them correctly. First point, the net positive interbank position, you're right, this is the first quarter with such a position. It comes from a very tight policy in terms of asset used throughout the group because liquidity is such an important and precious raw material that we have developed. And included in the management systems a number of mechanisms to save liquidity and to keep liquidity aside if possible.

We expect, and that's the strategic reason for such a move, that liquidity will become even more important in the competitive lever in the next month, so we want to be ready for that. The performance of bancassurance in the market, well, I agree. And but the evidence of the fact that when we decide to focus the efforts of the retained network in one direction, and that was the decision we took at the end of the first quarter, the results are remarkable. Now I'm not sure about the third question. I thought – I think that your question was about the P&L impact of the non-core asset disposal.
Exactly.

And that's not – it is something that we are not disclosing, but for sure the kind of, let's say, evaluation in prices we are getting for some of those will certainly not jeopardize the P&L position. But, again, we are not providing that figure. The restructuring charges, restructuring charges will – at the end of the business plan, in the three years will be certainly higher than what we had in the business plan, mainly because of the acquisitions we have made and because of the much higher number of people that will escort out that will leave the company during the three years.

Our best estimate, as of today, is that the 1.7 billion target we had in the business plan on restructuring integration charges will probably move up to 2.6 billion for paying for those several thousand people more, and the acquisitions we made. Tax rate, hard to do deregularized given the volatility of the finance law in – of the fiscal laws in our country, but after embedding the effect of the finance law for 2008 our best estimate is in the round of 33%.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Next question comes from Mr. Alessandro Roccati from FPK. Mr. Roccati, please proceed with your question.

Good afternoon, Mr. Passera. Four very quick questions. The first one is on risk-weighted assets. We've seen a decrease from 401 billion in the first quarter to 389 billion in the second quarter, I just wonder if you can give us a breakdown between the impact of Basel 2 and the actual risk-weighted assets increase? Looking at the loans, I can see a growth of 17%, so I would expect some sort of similar growth in risk-weighted assets if you can actually comment on this.
